🎯 Key Takeaways for quick navigation:  00:32 📚 Work in physics is the result of applying force over a distance to a system, and it is crucial to understand forces before delving into the concept of work. 01:54 📐 When the force applied is not in the exact direction of motion, the work equation involves the force, distance, and the cosine of the angle between the force and the direction of motion. 03:19 ⚖️ Work is measured in Joules, the same unit used for energy. Work is a change in energy, and energy is defined as the ability to do work. Two main types of energy discussed are kinetic energy and potential energy. 04:43 🌐 Potential energy can be gravitational or spring potential energy. Gravitational potential energy is calculated as mgh (mass times gravity times height), while spring potential energy is half times the spring constant times the distance squared. 06:39 🔄 Some systems can lose energy through work (non-conservative), but conservative systems, like a simple pendulum, do not lose energy. Energy changes between kinetic and potential, and their sum remains constant. 08:01 ⚡ Average power is defined as work over time, measured in Watts (Joules per second). It quantifies how much energy is converted from one form to another over time, with an example of calculating average power in pulling a box.  Made with HARPA AI

When you hear the word, "Work," what is the first thing you think of? Normal People: Briefcases, cubicles, offices, boredom? What else? Athletes: Working out at the gym? Training? Adults who forgot their lessons: Activity in which one exerts strength or faculties to do or perform something, whereas something is produced or accomplished by effort, exertion, or exercise of skill. Physics Geeks:  Work is done when a force that is applied to an object moves that object. The work is calculated by multiplying the force by the amount of movement of an object (W = F * d). A force of 10 newtons, that moves an object 3 meters, does 30 n-m of work. There is a way to deal with gravitational potential energy that isn't relative. It comes from the fact that, using E as all energies other than potential, Ei + PEgi = Ef + PEgf. That can be rewritten as Ef = Ei + PEgi - PEgf. If we expand PEg we get Ef = Ei + mghi - mghf, and then using the distributive property, Ef = Ei + mg(hi - hf). So basically, gravitational potential energy is more about a change in height than some abstract quantity associated with a certain height.

Thank you! So could you technically say that Kinetic Energy is the potential to do work and potential energy is the potential to have the potential?

Potential energy is the inherent energy possessed in a body due to it's position. May be gravitational, electrical etc. If you take gravitational potential energy, let's say at the top of a hill, the gravitational potential of a ball is the highest. As it falls down, the potential energy gets converted to kinetic energy. So the kinetic energy at the bottom is equal to the potential at the top. Another example: in a spring, the average force applied from rest to compressed state is -k/2 times x. The work done in compressing the spring is naturally -k/2 times x squared. This work done according to work energy theorem is stored as elastic potential energy and is interchangeable. So, that potential energy does work on an object which, let's say, requires a thrust from the compressed spring. Directly answering your question, both have the capacity to do work. Don't get confused with the word 'potential'. Cheers. 😊

Now , during it's motion the gravitational force acted on it downward but it moved upward . Notice that the direction of force and motion aare opposite to each other in this case . It took until college physics for my professors to explain just WHY this information is particularly useful.  Basically, you have all your forces, masses, distances, speeds, etc, all combined in such a way that you get a number that remains constant. This makes calculations far easier, and you can back track to get other values that may be a pain to calculate.  For instance, if you are calculating the speed of a roller coaster at the bottom of a hill, then without work-energy theorem, you would have to do a vector integral to add up all the forces on the car at every point in time.  With work-energy theorem, you know that the potential energy at the top of the hill is m x g x h. At the bottom of the hill, all that potential energy is now kinetic energy, which has the formula 1/2 x m x v^2. Since energy is conserved, you just have to throw them together. mgh=0.5mv^2. This simple equation takes into account all the changes in force over all time, but is astoundingly simple, because we are able to relate the properties of a system to a value that remains constant.  This may not seem like a big deal, but it really does go far in simplifying everything. Especially fluid dynamics. Though in fluid dynamics, we use a similar idea called "head". Its units are length. It is essentially energy of raising that particular fluid that distance. But this is also constant (unless there is a pump), so you can convert between velocity, height, and pressure fairly easily.

Kashim Akram This hypothesis proposes that our concept of "nothingness" may need to change. We naturally think of nothing as an absence of everything - a void of no activity, no "stuff". Thus you can't get "something from nothing".  But this may not be the case. "Nothing" may in fact be a place blazing with particles that continually pop in and out of existence, borrowing energy in order to exist and then repaying it back to the universe with annihilation. In quantum mechanics, this is known as "quantum fluctuations".  A practical example of this in action is Hawking radiation, whereby two particles at a black hole's event horizon pop into existence. One of the particles zooms off emitting radiation. The other particle goes into the black hole and promptly annihilates with an existing particle to cancel the debt that these two particles owe to the universe.  The actual fabric of spacetime itself may behave in this manner which is known as "quantum foam".

To all the answers already given I add one remark:  The video is not strictly correct that energy is always conserved. Noether's theorem relates energy conservation to time translation symmetry. If I do a set of experiments on a physical system today, and I repeat the experiments tomorrow (or any later time), and I find the same results, then the system is invariant under time translation, and only then is energy conserved. The condition of time translation invariance may appear to be trivial, but it is not.  In the context of cosmology it does not apply, because the universe is expanding. So if we study a system on a cosmological scale, an experiment at a later time is essentially different from an earlier one. For example, the density of the universe is less at the later time, and the temperature of the cosmic background radiation, and so on. In that case energy is not even EXPECTED to be conserved.  So even if you avoid extrapolating all the way back to the Big Bang, you simply do not expect, nor find, energy conservation on a cosmic scale.

Ellsworth Toohey The problem here is, that the law of energy conservation is of course only valid for a closed system, and the only closed system we know is the universe. So if due to expansion energy can get lost because of cosmological redshift, the law of energy conservation is no longer valid for ANY system.

Frank Schneider even though many classical cosmological models do not conserve energy, they can still keep track of the change in energy, so all the 'accounting' adds up.  Also for realistic cosmological models the difference is so minute that it could be discovered only by observing numerous and very distant supernovae.

The universe is not a closed system in any meaningful way. We do have lots of closed physical systems, however. It is build right into the heart of GR that locally physics is the same as in flat space. Many (local) phenomena in nature are not significantly affected by the cosmological expansion, and then the problem with energy conservation on a cosmic scale is irrelevant.

Ellsworth Toohey There is not a single closed system known except for the universe. If there are, would you be so kind, as to name some ? Apart from that is it irrelevant if the lw of conservation of energy is just violated a tiny bit or massively. A violation of a conservation law is a violation of a conservation law, no matter what.

A system is closed if its interaction with things outside it is negligible for the experiments you want to do. Examples: a girl on a swing, when I want to describe her motion within 10% accuracy over a few oscillations, a Cesium atom in an atomic clock when I want to measure its electronic transitions with 10 digit accuracy, the Earth-Sun system when I want to describe its motion at roughly percent level, and many others.  In GR the use of a Local Inertial System, e.g. a free falling reference frame, guarantees that locally (i.e. to the extent that tidal forces can be ignored) all physics goes through just like in flat spacetime.  In physics accuracy and error margins are always essential. Whether an effect is small or large matters greatly.  The universe, in the way it is usually understood, does not have any things outside it, so the concept of a closed system cannot be meaningfully applied to it.  The non-conservation of energy on a cosmic scale has little to do with the notion of a closed system, and everything with violation of time-invariance and Noether's theorem. The fact that invariance under time translation underlies energy conservation is not always fully appreciated, because in many simple situations (the ones  considered in school) a simpler conceptual framework suffices. In cosmology we are confronted with a situation where we have no everyday experience, and in which the simple framework fails, so that we need the more general approach using Noether's theorem.

No - they're not of the same scale.  For one thing, energy is a scalar, whereas momentum is a vector - but more importantly note that momentum is measured in newton-seconds, whereas a joule is a newton applied over a meter.  Or think of it this way - you differentiate momentum over time to get the force, then integrate that over a path in space to get the work, i.e., the change in energy.  That's the difference - time vs. space.

Momentum is a mathematical construct we use to describe motion. It's basically "amount of motion". It also has a direction, which is why we can use it to calculate how pool balls behave for example. Kinetic energy has no direction and is the value that can be converted directly into other forms of energy like potential, heat, electric, etc.

Momentum is a quantity that describes how difficult it is to bring a moving massive object to rest - or to change its motion. Also, in the absence of any forces (total) momentum will be conserved, and that's crucial for describing, say inelastc collisions. Kinetic energy is just the energy of motion. For free classical particles we have KE = (p^2) / (2m) In general, momentum and energy are related. Momentum is conserved if a system is translationally invariant (i.e. if you shove the system a bit, keeping everything else the same then the physics remains identical, just as if you didn't move everything. But if the system is sensitive to spatial translations, then that symmetry is destroyed and momentum may not be conserved). Similarly if a system has time translation symmetry, i.e. if you push it a bit in time instead of space, then the energy (kinetic plus potential energy) is conserved. So energy could be thought of like the time equivalent of momentum - in fact it is written as the time component of the 'four-momentum' (a vector of the energy and the three spatial components of momentum, which is commonly used in relativity). These are two instances of Noether's theorem (which broadly states that continuous symmetries imply conservation laws).

I know this is a pretty old thread but i just want to say, i think this particular crash course is aimed at high school students, so ages 14-18.   See, much of the material can be discussed to not only 7th graders, but 5th graders; but this course is bringing calculus into play. Barely. You can actually basically ignore the math in this series; it's just that you'd be missing out.  I think that many students are introduced to these CONCEPTS and a young age, but it's not usually presented in mathematical or even generally formal terms.   So, it doesn't surprise me that 7th graders would be taught these concepts, but i doubt they would be taught from a mathematical standpoint with rigorous effort such as to truly understand.   Hell, i've known about all of these concepts since 3rd grade; but i certainly didn't know any of the math, did not formally approach it, and probably would not have understood this series, nor the AP classes that it essentially overviews.   TLDR: Saying this is aimed at 7th graders is probably more than a little bit disingenuous. A 7th grader could understand the concepts, surely, but probably not the mathematics behind it, and wouldn't approach it with the seriousness required of the AP classes this series overviews.   It's like asking at what age people normally learn to swim. Technically a toddler can do it, but their "swimming" would probably amount to sitting in 5 inches of water and splashing around.
